description: Erection of single storey side/rear extensions following demolition of existing conservatory
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The finished floor levels of the development to which this permission relates shall be no lower than those of the existing building and any electrical sockets or other electrical fittings within the development shall be installed no lower than 750mm above finished floor level.Reason: To mitigate the risks associated with flooding of the site, in accordance with policy 5.12 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling within the Coombe Wood Conservation Area and is covered by an area Tree Protection order (TPO). The Coombe Hill Conservation Area encompasses the estate and hinterland to the demolished Coombe Warren, containing several mid 19th century properties by architect George Devey and other large interesting 20th century houses in a spacious landscaped setting, adjoining Coombe Hill Golf Course. The spacious landscaped setting contributes to the significance of the Conservation Area.ProposalDemolition of existing pool house and erection of a single storey pool house, plant room and bar.This application follows recently refused application 23/01096/HOU dated 04.07.2023 which was refused for the following reasons;1) The proposed development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the conservation area due to the loss of/harm to mature trees which contribute positively to the significance of the Conservation Area and there would be no public benefits to outweigh the identified less than substantial harm, thereby conflicting with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 and the NPPF (2021).2) The proposals require the removal of mature trees and the applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed development would not also result in harm to the health and longevity of other trees covered by a tree protection order through damage to its root protection area. The proposal would not accord with Policy G7 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Both reasons for refusal would need to be addressed in order for this application to be successful.Consultation5 Neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.Malden and Coombe Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee - no objection but questioned the possible impact on trees.RBK Tree and Landscape Officer - Although the Tree & Landscape Officer supports the sensitive redevelopment of this site and of the pool house, the Arboricultural submission needs to be more robust in order to adequately support the proposals. The Tree & Landscape Officer has reviewed the submitted supporting documentation and has identified the following issues:- The AIA / AMS does not go so far as to detail that existing foundations will be reused where possible including in the rebuilding of the boundary walls as incorporated within the walls of the new structures.- The existing site plan when compared to the proposed appears to show the wholesale removal of trees beneath T002 to the South West corner of the building but this is not clear within the AIA/AMS plans.- The "Construction Exclusion Zone" in the AIA/AMS plans covers the entirety of the proposal site which would clearly make the proposals impossible to achieve.- There are no details as to how investigations will be conducted to determine the need for special foundations within the RPA of T003 & T004.- There are no details as to what those special foundations might be and how they might be achieved.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on the Coombe Wood Conservation Area; and,- The impact of the development on Tree Preservation Orders.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed pool house would be acceptable with regards to scale, appearance and shape. However, the submitted Arboricultural Information is not robust enough to demonstrate that trees of amenity value within the Tree Preservation Order area would be adequately protected. It is noted that the trees on site and at neighbouring properties (as identified within the submitted Arboricultural Information) include Category B trees.As the area is well-treed with mature trees contributing to the character of the area, it is considered that harm to, or the loss of, trees of amenity value would result in an unacceptable adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area. Therefore, reason one for refusal has not been fully addressed and would still stand.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF 2023 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer Comment: As stated above, it is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the potential harm to, or loss of, mature trees of amenity value which contribute to the character of the area. It is noted that the significance of the Coombe Wood Conservation Area is in part derived from its open spaces and semi-rural character with soft landscaping and trees.Officers consider that the adverse impact arising from any harm to, or loss of, trees would amount to less than substantial harm to the significance of the Coombe Wood Conservation Area. It is therefore necessary to weigh this harm against any public benefits of the proposal. The applicant has not advanced any arguments as to the public benefits of the proposal, nor is it apparent to Officers that there would be any. The proposed development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the conservation area and there would be no public benefits to outweigh the identified less than substantial harm, thereby conflicting with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 and the NPPF (2023).TreesThe London Plan states that existing trees of value should be retained and any loss as a result of development should be replaced following the "right place, right tree" principle set out in the London Tree and Woodland Framework 2005. The LDF Core Strategy echoes this intention, stating that the Council will ensure new developments protect and promote biodiversity through, amongst other things, appropriate tree planting.The Residential Design SPD provides further guidance, with Policy Guidance 7 stating that there will generally be a presumption against the loss of trees, regardless of whether or not they are protected by a tree preservation order or their location within a conservation area. Where a development proposal involves the removal of a tree on the site, the applicant will be expected to demonstrate that the tree is in poor health and that two replacement trees can be provided to compensate for the loss of that tree.Officer Comment: As mentioned above, insufficient information has been submitted to satisfy the Tree & Landscape Officer that the previous issues raised in relation to harm to, or of loss of, trees of amenity value have been fully addressed. Therefore, it is still considered that the applicant has not demonstrated through the submission of cogent information that the proposed development would not result in harm to the health and longevity of trees covered by a tree protection order through damage to its root protection area. As the issues identified by the Tree & Landscape Officer concern foundations and special foundation designs it is considered that the necessary information could not be secured by way of a planning condition. The type of foundation could have implications for the design of the proposals and trees on site and it is therefore considered that this information must be submitted upfront.  ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
